home.faq1Answer: Yes! All EBODA tools are 100% free. You can use Color Wheel, Image Color Picker, Contrast Checker, and Gradient Generator without paying anything.
home.faq2Question: How to extract colors from an image?
home.faq2Answer: Use our Image Color Picker tool. Upload any image and click on points to extract colors. You'll automatically get HEX, RGB, and HSL codes.
home.faq3Question: What is the WCAG contrast checker?
home.faq3Answer: It's a tool that checks if your design's color combination meets WCAG accessibility standards. It indicates whether the contrast is sufficient for people with visual impairments.
home.faq4Question: Can I export the created palettes?
home.faq4Answer: Yes! You can export your palettes in various formats: CSS, SCSS, JSON, JavaScript, and even Tailwind CSS code. Just create your palette and click export.

about.title: About Us
about.missionText: EBODA was born from the frustration of designers and developers with the complexity and time spent choosing perfect color palettes. Our mission is to simplify color creation, making harmony and chromatic accessibility instant and intuitive.
about.beliefText: We believe that color is the most powerful language of design, and our platform is the tool that translates this language into practical and innovative results.
about.offerIntro: We are an innovative SaaS focused on accelerating color workflow. Our main tools include:
about.imageColorPickerDesc: Extract dominant and specific colors from any image with pixel precision.
about.colorWheelInteractiveDesc: Explore color relationships, harmonies and contrasts in real time.
about.colorLibraryDesc: A vast catalog of popular colors and trends, with detailed information on accessibility and usage.
about.technologyText: Built with Next.js for performance, Tailwind CSS for agile design and Supabase for scalability and data security. We use advanced Artificial Intelligence models to ensure that each generated palette is not only beautiful, but also functional and aligned with design best practices.

colorGuide.pageSubtitle: Master color theory and transform your projects with harmonious and impactful palettes
colorGuide.introP1: Color theory is a set of principles used to create harmonious color combinations. It explains how humans perceive colors and the visual effects of how colors mix, combine or contrast with each other.
colorGuide.introP2: Understanding color theory is essential for designers, artists, developers and anyone who works with visual communication. A good choice of colors can convey emotions, create visual hierarchy and improve user experience.
colorGuide.hueDesc: The name of the pure color (red, blue, yellow)
colorGuide.saturationDesc: The intensity or purity of the color
colorGuide.lightnessDesc: How light or dark the color is
colorGuide.colorWheelP1: The color wheel is a circular representation of colors based on the three primary colors. It was developed by Isaac Newton in 1666 and is the basis for understanding color relationships.
colorGuide.primaryColorsDesc: Cannot be created by mixing other colors. They are the basis of all others.
colorGuide.secondaryColorsDesc: Created by mixing two primary colors in equal parts.
colorGuide.tertiaryColorsDesc: Created by mixing a primary color with an adjacent secondary color.
colorGuide.harmoniesP1: Color harmonies are combinations that work well together, creating visual balance and a pleasant aesthetic. There are several classic harmonies based on the positions of colors on the color wheel.
colorGuide.complementaryDesc: Two opposite colors on the color wheel. Creates high contrast and visual energy. Ideal for highlighting important elements.
colorGuide.analogousDesc: Three adjacent colors on the color wheel. Creates harmonious and serene designs. Widely used in landscapes and nature.
colorGuide.triadicDesc: Three equidistant colors on the color wheel (forming a triangle). Vibrant and balanced, common in children's and playful designs.
colorGuide.splitComplementaryDesc: A base color and the two colors adjacent to its complement. Offers contrast with less tension than pure complementary.
colorGuide.tetradicDesc: Four colors forming a rectangle on the wheel. Rich in possibilities, but requires careful balance between warm and cool colors.
colorGuide.monochromaticDesc: Variations of a single color (different saturations and lightnesses). Elegant, cohesive and easy to implement. Ideal for minimalist designs.
colorGuide.temperatureP1: Colors are classified as warm or cool based on the psychological sensations they evoke. This division is fundamental to creating specific atmospheres in your projects.
colorGuide.psychologyP1: Each color evokes specific emotions and associations. Understanding color psychology helps convey the right message to your target audience.
colorGuide.contrastP1: Color contrast is crucial for readability and accessibility. WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) define minimum contrast standards.
colorGuide.contrastTipText2: to check if your color combinations meet WCAG standards.
colorGuide.applicationP1: Applying color theory in practice requires balance. Here are some rules and tips for creating effective palettes.
colorGuide.tip1: Start with 2-3 colors and add saturation/lightness variations
colorGuide.tip2: Use neutral colors (white, black, gray) as a base for visual rest
colorGuide.tip3: Test your colors on different devices and lighting conditions
colorGuide.tip4: Consider color blindness: avoid red/green as the only differentiation
colorGuide.tip5: Maintain consistency: use the same colors for the same functions
